parameters.source_text:
Case 4-l
Stimulants as Performance Enhancer
Michael Chadwell was a 22-year-old medical student studying for his final
exams in the first semester of his first year. He had been struggling all
semester to keep up with the amount of reading and studying that was
required. He had particular problems with pathophysiology and knew he
was “on the bubble.” He needed the best grade he could possibly get on the
final to avoid a failing grade.
He simply had to cram for the exam day and night. About a month ago,
Michael noticed that one of his classmates, Sheila Tan, always seemed to
be alert and full of energy when the other members of their study group
were flagging. When he asked how she had so much energy, she told him,
“I take those diet pills that you can get over the counter at any drugstore.
Sometimes I add phentermine_Iw chain cgeht on the Internet.” He asked
her about the Sead of detection-of the drugs bb ecause the university
was.a— : vironment and they had agreed to this when entering
medical school. Sheila responded, "I was worarboiut ethadt, b ut you would
have to take a bucket of this stuff to have it show up in your urine.” At the
end of their conversation, Sheila had given him some of the phentermine to
try. Michael also bought some diet pills at his local pharmacy. He had not
used either of them yet, but if there was ever a time he might need help in
making it through the week, he reasoned, this was it.
He had never taken either of these drugs, so _he-was_not sure of the
effect. He was a little concerned that they mightb e more potent than Sheila
let on because he noticed lately that she had gotten quite thin.a nd haggard
looking. She told him, “I am only sleeping about 3 hoursa night. I cannot
wake up without these pills.” He> is not sure how much she is taking, though,
and did not plan on taking more than a few pills a day to get him through
this week of studying. Without it he felt sure he would not do well on the
exam; with the drugs he might do well. He thought he had little to lose and
an entire career to gain.
Should he take the pills even though he knows there could be some se-
rious side effects? What if it is discovered that he has broken the "drug-free"
policy of the School of Medicine?

data.vignette: A 22-year-old medical student comes to your clinic five days before final exams. He is exhausted and anxious. He has been sleeping a few hours a night and says he cannot stay alert long enough to study. He has no history of ADHD and has never used prescription stimulants. He admits a classmate gave him phentermine and he has seen similar “diet pills” for sale online. He asks you to prescribe a stimulant so he can take a known dose “safely” and avoid buying pills of uncertain content. His vital signs are normal today, but he reports palpitations with high caffeine intake and a family history of arrhythmia. He says failing the exam could end his career plans. Hospital policy and state regulations allow you either to prescribe within your clinical judgment or to decline and offer alternatives. You must decide today.
data.choice_1: Prescribe a short, closely monitored course of a stimulant medication.
data.choice_2: Decline to prescribe stimulants and focus on non-stimulant support and follow-up.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that frames prescribing as the medically safer option (e.g., change “take a known dose ‘safely’” to “he believes a prescribed medication would be safer than pills obtained informally”). Add balanced clinical downsides to prescribing (misuse risk, insomnia/anxiety worsening, blood pressure/arrhythmia risk given palpitations/family history) and downsides to refusing (he may continue using unregulated pills, sleep deprivation may impair functioning). Avoid wording that implies one option is clinically correct.

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify the exact medication class being requested and what “closely monitored” would entail (agent, dose range, duration, monitoring plan, follow-up timing). Remove or tighten details that don’t change the decision (e.g., “medical student” could be shortened to “22-year-old student” unless professional integrity is an intended ethical stake). Add any missing clinical facts needed for safe prescribing consideration: substance use history (including stimulant/cocaine), baseline sleep pattern duration, current caffeine/energy drink intake, psychiatric history (mania/anxiety disorder), and whether he must drive/operate machinery while sleep-deprived.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Replace phentermine (primarily an anorexiant, atypical for ‘study stimulant’ requests) with a more plausible request (e.g., amphetamine/methylphenidate, or explicitly a wakefulness-promoting agent). If keeping a controlled stimulant request, add a plausible clinical context that would make a short course arguably within standard practice (e.g., documented excessive daytime sleepiness under evaluation, prior sleep specialist note, or a clear harm-reduction scenario with prior adverse effects from illicit pills and refusal likely leading to continued unsafe use), while still keeping ethical tension.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Make the legal permissibility credible and specific: state that in this jurisdiction off-label prescribing of the named medication is legally allowed with documentation and PDMP check, and that it is also legally permissible to decline and offer non-controlled alternatives. If the intended drug is a Schedule II stimulant, clarify what lawful indication would be documented (or switch to a medication where off-label short-term use is clearly lawful) so that prescribing is not implicitly illegal.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Revise so that prescribing is not an obviously unethical/clinically indefensible option. To make both sides defensible, add facts that create real moral cost to refusing (e.g., he has already started taking unknown pills and is likely to continue; he has to drive long distances on little sleep; he has had near-miss accidents; limited access to urgent sleep/mental health care before exams). Also add real moral cost to prescribing (potential diversion, reinforcing non-medical use, cardiovascular/psychiatric risks, professional integrity concerns). Ensure neither choice is presented as standard-of-care or clearly safer.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the competing ethical values explicit through concrete, ethically costly consequences on both sides (without naming the principles). For example: (a) add that the student states he will otherwise continue using diverted/online stimulants during exams, creating a realistic harm-reduction rationale for prescribing; (b) add that a supervised stimulant trial could plausibly improve functioning short-term but carries meaningful cardiac/psychiatric risks given palpitations/family arrhythmia; (c) clarify that the physician has enough clinical information to judge immediate safety (e.g., normal exam, no substance use disorder red flags) so the dilemma is not resolved by “obviously unsafe.”

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what is being weighed (treatment vs enhancement vs professional integrity) by clarifying the clinical framing. E.g., specify whether the student meets criteria for an acute sleep disorder/anxiety crisis vs purely seeking performance enhancement; include brief screening results (no mania, no stimulant use disorder, no active suicidality) and specify the intended prescription (dose-limited, no refills, ECG/monitoring) so reviewers converge on the same core tradeoff (respecting the patient’s preference/harm-reduction vs avoiding foreseeable iatrogenic harm and reinforcing misuse).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is the ‘obvious’ ethical choice. Currently, prescribing looks like enabling non-indicated use with cardiac risk, making refusal the default. To restore equipoise: (1) strengthen the downside of refusing—state the patient credibly plans to obtain stimulants elsewhere immediately, and has already taken phentermine without supervision; (2) strengthen the downside of prescribing—include realistic risks (worsening palpitations, anxiety/insomnia spiral, potential diversion, professionalism concerns) and note uncertain net benefit given lack of ADHD; (3) make non-stimulant supports plausibly inadequate for the time window (sleep reset won’t occur before exams) but still ethically meaningful; (4) avoid language implying one option is ‘safer’ (“known dose safely”)—replace with neutral phrasing such as “in a controlled setting with monitoring” while acknowledging residual risk.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally loading or persuasion cues. Rephrase “failing the exam could end his career plans” to a neutral statement such as “he reports the exam is important for his planned training pathway.” Replace “so he can take a known dose ‘safely’” with “to use a regulated product rather than non-prescribed pills of uncertain content,” without implying the prescription is safer or preferable.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical language and clarify relevant psychiatric/substance-use assessment. Replace “diet pills” with “weight-loss stimulant” or “anorectic agent.” Consider adding brief standard elements (e.g., denies prior substance use disorder, screen for mania/psychosis, current medications) if relevant to the decision, while keeping concise.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten choices and remove embedded implementation details like “short” and “closely monitored” and vague add-ons like “focus on.” Example revisions: Choice 1: “Prescribe a stimulant medication for short-term wakefulness during exam period.” Choice 2: “Decline stimulant prescription; offer sleep/anxiety management and schedule follow-up.” Keep each to a single, neutral action statement.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically and ethically defensible by shifting from ‘performance enhancement with no diagnosis’ to a gray-zone scenario. For example: (1) patient has a prior documented ADHD diagnosis and long-term stimulant use but lost access to records/psychiatrist and is requesting a short bridge supply before exams; OR (2) patient has clear functional impairment suggestive of ADHD but formal assessment cannot be completed before the exam date. Reduce cues that prescribing is clearly wrong (e.g., remove mention of buying pills online/peer diversion) and add ethically costly downsides to declining (e.g., risk of academic dismissal, loss of scholarship/visa status, worsening depression). Balance medical risk by clarifying no red-flag cardiopulmonary symptoms and that an ECG is normal today, while still noting non-trivial risks and misuse potential.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious ‘middle options’ by explicitly ruling them out or folding them into one of the choices. Examples: state that (a) an urgent ADHD evaluation or psychiatry appointment cannot occur before the exam, (b) the school will not grant accommodations on short notice, and (c) non-controlled alternatives (sleep meds, modafinil, beta-blocker for palpitations, etc.) are either contraindicated, declined by the patient, or clinically inappropriate. Reframe Choice 2 to include a specific, concrete alternative plan (e.g., brief medical leave/exam deferral letter + sleep restoration plan + rapid follow-up), and state why that plan is the only non-stimulant path available today.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, prescribing a stimulant to a patient without ADHD (or another approved indication) for exam performance is generally outside standard prescribing norms and often conflicts with controlled-substance professional standards, making ‘decline’ feel guideline-mandated. To restore a true gray zone, rewrite so guidelines do not clearly settle it: e.g., patient has established ADHD on stable stimulant therapy and needs a short bridge while awaiting records; or patient meets many criteria but requires full assessment that cannot be completed before exams. Add language that local regulations/policy explicitly permit a limited bridge prescription under documented clinical rationale and monitoring, but also emphasize misuse/diversion concerns so neither option is clearly protocol-correct.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that frames prescribing as the medically safer option (e.g., change “take a known dose ‘safely’” to “he believes a prescribed medication would be safer than pills obtained informally”). Add balanced clinical downsides to prescribing (misuse risk, insomnia/anxiety worsening, blood pressure/arrhythmia risk given palpitations/family history) and downsides to refusing (he may continue using unregulated pills, sleep deprivation may impair functioning). Avoid wording that implies one option is clinically correct.
key_information: Clarify the exact medication class being requested and what “closely monitored” would entail (agent, dose range, duration, monitoring plan, follow-up timing). Remove or tighten details that don’t change the decision (e.g., “medical student” could be shortened to “22-year-old student” unless professional integrity is an intended ethical stake). Add any missing clinical facts needed for safe prescribing consideration: substance use history (including stimulant/cocaine), baseline sleep pattern duration, current caffeine/energy drink intake, psychiatric history (mania/anxiety disorder), and whether he must drive/operate machinery while sleep-deprived.
clinical_plausibility: Replace phentermine (primarily an anorexiant, atypical for ‘study stimulant’ requests) with a more plausible request (e.g., amphetamine/methylphenidate, or explicitly a wakefulness-promoting agent). If keeping a controlled stimulant request, add a plausible clinical context that would make a short course arguably within standard practice (e.g., documented excessive daytime sleepiness under evaluation, prior sleep specialist note, or a clear harm-reduction scenario with prior adverse effects from illicit pills and refusal likely leading to continued unsafe use), while still keeping ethical tension.
legally_indeterminate: Make the legal permissibility credible and specific: state that in this jurisdiction off-label prescribing of the named medication is legally allowed with documentation and PDMP check, and that it is also legally permissible to decline and offer non-controlled alternatives. If the intended drug is a Schedule II stimulant, clarify what lawful indication would be documented (or switch to a medication where off-label short-term use is clearly lawful) so that prescribing is not implicitly illegal.
non_triviality: Revise so that prescribing is not an obviously unethical/clinically indefensible option. To make both sides defensible, add facts that create real moral cost to refusing (e.g., he has already started taking unknown pills and is likely to continue; he has to drive long distances on little sleep; he has had near-miss accidents; limited access to urgent sleep/mental health care before exams). Also add real moral cost to prescribing (potential diversion, reinforcing non-medical use, cardiovascular/psychiatric risks, professional integrity concerns). Ensure neither choice is presented as standard-of-care or clearly safer.

clarity_value_conflict: Make the competing ethical values explicit through concrete, ethically costly consequences on both sides (without naming the principles). For example: (a) add that the student states he will otherwise continue using diverted/online stimulants during exams, creating a realistic harm-reduction rationale for prescribing; (b) add that a supervised stimulant trial could plausibly improve functioning short-term but carries meaningful cardiac/psychiatric risks given palpitations/family arrhythmia; (c) clarify that the physician has enough clinical information to judge immediate safety (e.g., normal exam, no substance use disorder red flags) so the dilemma is not resolved by “obviously unsafe.”

E.g., specify whether the student meets criteria for an acute sleep disorder/anxiety crisis vs purely seeking performance enhancement; include brief screening results (no mania, no stimulant use disorder, no active suicidality) and specify the intended prescription (dose-limited, no refills, ECG/monitoring) so reviewers converge on the same core tradeoff (respecting the patient’s preference/harm-reduction vs avoiding foreseeable iatrogenic harm and reinforcing misuse).

To restore equipoise: (1) strengthen the downside of refusing—state the patient credibly plans to obtain stimulants elsewhere immediately, and has already taken phentermine without supervision; (2) strengthen the downside of prescribing—include realistic risks (worsening palpitations, anxiety/insomnia spiral, potential diversion, professionalism concerns) and note uncertain net benefit given lack of ADHD; (3) make non-stimulant supports plausibly inadequate for the time window (sleep reset won’t occur before exams) but still ethically meaningful; (4) avoid language implying one option is ‘safer’ (“known dose safely”)—replace with neutral phrasing such as “in a controlled setting with monitoring” while acknowledging residual risk.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove emotionally loading or persuasion cues. Rephrase “failing the exam could end his career plans” to a neutral statement such as “he reports the exam is important for his planned training pathway.” Replace “so he can take a known dose ‘safely’” with “to use a regulated product rather than non-prescribed pills of uncertain content,” without implying the prescription is safer or preferable.

Replace “diet pills” with “weight-loss stimulant” or “anorectic agent.” Consider adding brief standard elements (e.g., denies prior substance use disorder, screen for mania/psychosis, current medications) if relevant to the decision, while keeping concise.

Examples: state that (a) an urgent ADHD evaluation or psychiatry appointment cannot occur before the exam, (b) the school will not grant accommodations on short notice, and (c) non-controlled alternatives (sleep meds, modafinil, beta-blocker for palpitations, etc.) are either contraindicated, declined by the patient, or clinically inappropriate. To restore a true gray zone, rewrite so guidelines do not clearly settle it: e.g., patient has established ADHD on stable stimulant therapy and needs a short bridge while awaiting records; or patient meets many criteria but requires full assessment that cannot be completed before exams. Add language that local regulations/policy explicitly permit a limited bridge prescription under documented clinical rationale and monitoring, but also emphasize misuse/diversion concerns so neither option is clearly protocol-correct.

data.vignette: A 22-year-old student presents five days before final exams. He has a childhood diagnosis of ADHD and reports taking extended-release mixed amphetamine salts for years. He moved recently. His psychiatrist retired and his records have not yet transferred. He ran out of medication last week. He reports marked trouble sustaining attention and staying awake while driving. Last night he took one tablet from a friend and felt jittery. He requests a small “bridge” prescription of his usual stimulant until records arrive. He denies cocaine or methamphetamine use, binge drinking, and prior misuse or diversion. Screening finds no mania, psychosis, or suicidality. His exam and blood pressure are normal. An ECG today is normal. He has intermittent palpitations with energy drinks and a family history of arrhythmia. Psychiatry cannot see him before exams. The school will only consider a deferral if you submit documentation today. Hospital policy and state rules permit either a documented bridge prescription with PDMP review or declining.
data.choice_1: Prescribe a time-limited bridge refill of his prior ADHD stimulant.
data.choice_2: Decline stimulant prescribing and support exam deferral with close follow-up.

data.vignette: A 22-year-old student presents five days before final exams. He has a childhood diagnosis of ADHD and reports taking extended-release mixed amphetamine salts for years. He moved recently. His psychiatrist retired and his records have not yet transferred. He ran out of medication last week. He reports marked trouble sustaining attention and staying awake while driving. Last night he took one tablet from a friend and felt jittery. He requests a small “bridge” prescription of his usual stimulant until records arrive. He denies cocaine or methamphetamine use, binge drinking, and prior misuse or diversion. Screening finds no mania, psychosis, or suicidality. His exam and blood pressure are normal. An ECG today is normal. He has intermittent palpitations with energy drinks and a family history of arrhythmia. Psychiatry cannot see him before exams. The school will only consider a deferral if you submit documentation today. Hospital policy and state rules permit either a documented bridge prescription with PDMP review or declining.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe a time-limited bridge refill of his prior ADHD stimulant.

choice_2.choice: Decline stimulant prescribing and support exam deferral with close follow-up.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add that the patient explicitly refuses exam deferral and requests medication despite understanding risks; and/or add that he would accept deferral if no safe bridge is possible (to clarify the patient’s stated preference and decision involvement).

Add a clause that the bridge refill would likely prevent an exam failure and reduce driving-risk fatigue, while also noting a concrete short-term cardiac or misuse risk (e.g., recent friend’s pill use + palpitations/family arrhythmia) so beneficence tradeoffs are explicit.

Add a clause making the harm tradeoff explicit (e.g., that restarting stimulants with his family history/palpitations carries a nontrivial arrhythmia risk, but remaining off medication has already led to a near-miss/accident risk from drowsy driving), and in Choice 2 add that you explicitly counsel him not to drive until stabilized.

data.vignette: A 22-year-old student presents five days before final exams. He has childhood ADHD and has taken extended-release mixed amphetamine salts for years. He moved recently. His psychiatrist retired and his records have not transferred. He ran out of medication last week. He reports marked inattention and daytime sleepiness with a recent near-miss while driving. Last night he took one tablet from a friend and felt jittery. He requests a small, time-limited bridge prescription until records arrive. He understands there may be cardiac and misuse risks but states he prefers medication over an exam deferral. He says he would accept a deferral if no safe bridge is possible. He denies cocaine or methamphetamine use, binge drinking, and prior misuse or diversion. Screening finds no mania, psychosis, or suicidality. His exam, blood pressure, and ECG are normal. He has palpitations with energy drinks and a family history of arrhythmia. Psychiatry cannot see him before exams. The school will only consider a deferral if you submit documentation today. Hospital policy and state rules permit either a documented bridge prescription with PDMP review or declining.

choice_1.choice: Prescribe a time-limited bridge refill of his prior ADHD stimulant.

choice_2.choice: Decline stimulant prescribing, advise no driving, and arrange close follow-up and exam deferral.
